repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
On Windows, `explorer.exe` fails to open some URLs, for example:

    :lua vim.ui.open('https://devdocs.io/#q=lua%20lua_call')

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23401#issuecomment-1641015704

Solution:
Use rundll32 instead.

comment_data.body: I don't think `start` is an executable. You need to run it in `cmd.exe`. Or maybe just remove this branch and always use `rundll32` directly?
I dont think start is even necessary

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -134,8 +135,11 @@ describe('vim.ui', function()
 
   describe('open()', function()
     it('validation', function()
-      if is_ci('github') then
-        matches('vim.ui.open: command failed %(%d%): { "[^"]+", "non%-existent%-file" }',
+      if is_os('win') or not is_ci('github') then
+        exec_lua[[vim.system = function() return { wait=function() return { code=3} end } end]]
+      end
+      if not is_os('bsd') then

comment_data.body: I don't think that makes sense. The above block is setting up a mock for this block.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -134,8 +135,11 @@ describe('vim.ui', function()
 
   describe('open()', function()
     it('validation', function()
-      if is_ci('github') then

comment_regular_data.body: Tested on windows 11 works on powershell & cmd

@mrshmllow  I had confirmed that with this fix vim.ui.open works as expected on Windows.

Will be necessary just an update on the docs for the new approach.
it's kind of insane if rundll32 is not found but who knows with windows

The ui.open() test is failing on Windows:

```
ERROR    test/functional\lua\ui_spec.lua @ 136: vim.ui open() validation
test\helpers.lua:138: bad argument #1 to 'match' (string expected, got userdata)

stack traceback:
	test\helpers.lua:138: in function 'matches'
	test/functional\lua\ui_spec.lua:138: in function <test/functional\lua\ui_spec.lua:136>
investigating that error, it might be because system() errors, something about `timeout`
@adelarsq what does `:lua vim.print(vim.ui.open('non-existent-file'))` show on Windows?

> what does :lua vim.print(vim.ui.open('non-existent-file')) show on Windows?

@justinmk It shows this:

```
{
  code = 0,
  signal = 0,
  stderr = "",
  stdout = ""
}
nil  
```

> > what does :lua vim.print(vim.ui.open('non-existent-file')) show on Windows?
> 
> @justinmk It shows this:

@adelarsq that's with the changes from this PR, correct?  The tests are still failing because `vim.NIL` is returned:

```
ERROR    test/functional\lua\ui_spec.lua @ 136: vim.ui open() validation
test\helpers.lua:138: bad argument #1 to 'match' (string expected, got userdata)
	test/functional\lua\ui_spec.lua:138: in function <test/functional\lua\ui_spec.lua:136>
```

This suggests that `rundll32` with 'non-existent-file' silently fails. So `vim.ui.open()` can never report a failed URL.

If that's correct, then we need to skip the test on Windows (`is_os('win')`)). :(

> that's with the changes from this PR, correct?]

@justinmk  Yes.

> If that's correct, then we need to skip the test on Windows (is_os('win'))). :(

I think so. It returns nil even for successful ones:  

```lua
lua vim.print(vim.ui.open('www.google.com'))
```

Shows:

```
{
  code = 0,
  signal = 0,
  stderr = "",
  stdout = ""
}
nil   
```

> I think so. It returns nil even for successful ones: 

That's expected. It should return non-nil for failures only.
Doesn't that mean it never fails?

> Doesn't that mean it never fails?

Right, in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24392#issuecomment-1642135214 by "silently fails" I mean that `rundll32` doesn't return a non-zero exit code, despite the fact that it didn't handle `non-existent-file` in a useful way.
I am already using the patch here. Working as expected for every link so far.
Waiting for test to be fixed (see above comments)

maybe we manually check if the file exists or not..?

Does the api really need to guarrentee that the URI was opened properly? It is only used to report back to the LSP
Does the file really have to exist? @justinmk

File doesn't need to exist, it could be a URL. Or whatever else is handled by the "system handler". We don't know what is supported by which handler, we just sent a string that looks like a filepath or URI (which can have unlimited "schemes").

> Does the api really need to guarrentee that the URI was opened properly? It is only used to report back to the LSP

? If open() fails the user sees an error message. That is useful feedback. But if rundll32 fails silently there's nothing we can do.

Thus the only thing blocking this PR... is fixing the test.

I did some research on this so the conclusion is that `rundll32` command itself does not have a built-in mechanism for returning status. I also did some tests with `explorer`, `start` and `cmd` commands. So a test for this behaviour doesn't mean so much.

@justinmk Would be possible a mock around the behaviour for testing pourposes?
Why would we mock? The test works on non-Windows. Just skip that part of the test in Windows, as I suggested above, by checking `is_os()` in the test.
It only works on non-Windows by accident. If there is indeed an program that can open `nom-existent-file` then it won't work.

> It only works on non-Windows by accident. If there is indeed an program that can open `nom-existent-file` then it won't work.

How is that an accident? None of these handlers on any OS, currently, can open `non-existent-file`. It's just a Windows quirk that rundll32 doesn't report a failure even though it failed.

If that changes in the future (e.g. OS "open handlers" handle non-existent files by opening in a text editor), we can of course revisit the test.

In any case the point of the test is to test handler failure. If there's a better way to trigger "handler failure" then the test can use that.
Pushed a fix for the test.

> None of these handlers on any OS, currently, can open `non-existent-file`. It's just a Windows quirk that rundll32 doesn't report a failure even though it failed.

For me `xdg-open` can do that.

> Why would we mock? The test works on non-Windows. Just skip that part of the test in Windows, as I suggested above, by checking is_os() in the test.

@justinmk  I did take a look on rundll to solve this issue and for now there is no good way to make it returns. So something like you did on this https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24392/commits/83d4fdbf01f2592ca463b93ed0f484f1679f75ce I think is the best approach.
Thanks @justinmk

title: fix(ui.open): some URLs fail on Windows
